title: If a company goes out of business and is no longer operating in the state of California, are you still liable for that contract?
question: The Right One went out of business and is no longer operating in the state of California. However, it opened a new company in the same location and doing the same type of work. Is a person still liable for the contract under the new company even though no new paperwork was signed?
answers: I agree - you're going to have to review the language of the original contract to see if performance was assignable. Even if it was, you'll need more information on 'demise' of the old company to determine the relationship between it and the new company.

Companies usually don't just "go out of business," they either file for bankruptcy, and a trusee takes possession of and manages or sells its assets, including contractual ones, or they get bought out by or merge with another company, and the buyer often gets assigned the assets. Sometimes they do just dissolve, but in that case, the company has to settle its debts (and likely its receivables). Also, as noted by my colleague, the contract may be assignable by them, and may have been assigned to another company.

It's never wise to sign something you don't fully understand. Either review this contract (and whatever demand you may have gotten) and try to figure out what your respective rights and remedies are, or hire a lawyer to help you,

If the company with whom you had a contract had the right to assign the benefits of that contract, and did so, you could still be liable for your end of the bargain to the company to whom the contract was assigned. You should have a lawyer review the contract and contact the new company to ask them on what basis they think they have a right to hold you up to your end of the contract (assuming that's their position)

No. You have no liability to the new company unless you signed an agreement with them or with the old company allowing your contract to be transferred to the new company.
